Award.AwardTitle: Catching a New Wave: Gravitational-wave Astronomy as a Probe of the Universe
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides support for a new and innovative outreach project in the nascent field of gravitational-wave astrophysics. The project is timed to coincide with the International Year of Astronomy (IYA) 2009 and the World Science Festival (WSF) in New York City, June 2009. The LIGO exhibit will convey to its visitor three main concepts: the LIGO scientific endeavor is motivated by the same curiosity which motivated Galileo four hundred years ago; the violent Universe is awash with gravitational waves but at the moment these phenomena are entirely unexplored; giant, new \telescopes" are needed to detect the gravitational-wave spectrum and the technology of these telescopes is pushing back the frontiers of many scientific fields. The LIGO exhibit will comprise the following elements: a fully interactive laser interferometer; a large-scale three-dimensional LED artwork; large-screen multimedia presentations on gravitational wave astronomy; an interactive `Black Hole hunter' computer game. The design, integration and implementation of the exhibit elements will be achieved in partnership with professional exhibit designers. This award is cofunded by the Physics Division, the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities, and the Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The exhibit Astronomy?'s New Messengers: Listening to the Universe with Gravitational Waves remains to date one of the major outreach efforts of the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) Scientific Collaboration (LSC). Over the five-year duration of the award, a traveling version of Astronomy?'s New Messengers  traveled to dozens of colleges, universities, museums and street fairs throughout the United States. An extended, approximately 1000 sq. ft. version of the exhibit was unveiled at the 2010 World Science Festival in New York City, June 2-6, 2010, alongside a signature event on the theme of gravitational-wave astronomy featuring high-profile keynote speakers and artists. This exhibit was later displayed in three other U.S. venues. Both installations were designed and realized by multi-disciplinary firms of architects, designers, and educators providing award-winning architecture and exhibit design services. A NYC-based art studio which specializes in creating lighting environments for architectural and public spaces all over the world designed and realized the artistic component of the extended exhibit. Faculty, researchers, staff, graduate and undergraduate students from various LSC institutions contributed to concept development and educational ancillary activitties.

Intellectual Merit

Astronomy'?s New Messengers aimed to increase interest in, and understanding of, astronomy and the science of gravitational waves through a new culture blending art and science. The LIGO scientific endeavor is motivated by the same desire for exploration, the curiosity for the unknown and the awe of nature which motivated humankind throughout millennia of history. In this respect, science and art are two facets of the same human quest for beauty and truth. The project achieved this blend by locating Astronomy'?s New Messengers in prominent locations across the U.S. which ensured a high public profile and a large audience. Visitors had the opportunity to pause and reflect on the Universe, and their relationship to it, gaining notions of fundamental science and astronomy in an informal setting. The main target audience of the exhibit was an adolescent and young adult population of students, occasional visitors, and informal learners. To attract this difficult audience, the exhibit included possibilities  for age-appropriate self exploration and a messaging that allowed visitors to first discover their own excitement in the material, and then delve deeper into its complexity.

Broader impacts

Astronomy's New Messengers touched the lives of thousands of visitors of all ages, from K-12 school children and their families, to college students and senior citizens. It improved science literacy among the youth, diverse and underserved segments of the population, and the general public. It brought science and technology interactive experiences to areas where STEM educational experiences are plenty, as in large urban centers like Stanford, NYC, Chicago, as well as to areas where these experiences are scarce, such as small towns in Mississippi, Arkansas, Oklahoma. Increasing the awareness of current scientific research in these segments of the U.S. society promoted the growth of scientific advancement in these regions, increased educational opportunities in STEM disciplines, and enhanced diversity in science. Approximately 80% of the respondents to a survey stated that the exhibit helped them ?very much? or ?some? to understand what is LIGO and how it works, and what are gravitational waves. Over 70% of the respondents stated that the exhibit increased their awe of nature and interest in science.
